Award.AwardTitle: Molecular Theory and Simulation of Vibrational and Electronic Relaxation and Spectra in Liquid Solution
Award.AbstractNarration:
Eitan Geva of the University of Michigan is supported by an award from the Chemical Theory, Models and Computational Methods program to carry out research on the development of theoretical and computational tools that would provide an atomistically detailed description of a wide range of nonequilibrium electronic, vibrational and conformational processes and their spectroscopic signature. This study involves method development in the context of recent experimental measurements of vibrational energy relaxation rates of polar and ionic species in polar and protic solvents, multidimensional infrared spectra of the hydroxyl stretch in alcohols and of the carbonyl stretch in metal-carbonyl complexes and solvent effects on isomerization rates in liquid solution. These studies also involve collaborations with experimentalists and theorists who are colleagues in Geva's department.

Vibrational and electronic relaxation is inherent to nearly all processes that are important in chemistry, including many that have relevance to biological systems. Nonlinear optical spectroscopic techniques are powerful probes of the structure and dynamics of complex systems. Theoretical methods, such as those developed by the PI and his research group, are indispensible for interpreting these spectra. The work is having a broader impact through the training of students at all levels, curriculum development and the dissemination of computer codes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Recent advances in optical spectroscopic techniques have made it possible to probe the molecular dynamics of complex systems with unprecedentedly high temporal and spatial resolution. The interpretation of these experiments calls for the development of sophisticated theoretical and computational tools that would be able to provide a self-consistent and atomistically-detailed description of a wide range of the molecular dynamics underlying technologically- and biologically-relevant chemical systems, as well as their spectroscopic signature. We developed such tools in the context of experiments that probe the dynamics of liquid alcohols, which are widely used as solvents, fuels and model systems for understanding hydrogen-bonding.

 The funded research projects included a major educational component. K12, undergraduate and graduate students and postdocs were trained in modern chemical modeling and advanced computational techniques, with a strong commitment to enhancing diversity in the scientific community and broadening the participation of underrepresented groups in the scientific endeavor. Participants also received extensive training that prepared them for an independent career in an academic institution, government lab or industry. This training included the development of written and verbal communication skills, team work and management skills and opportunities for networking with potential employers. Finally, the funded research projects also contributed to building a strong and visible Theoretical Chemistry community at the University of Michigan via curriculum development, organization of professional meetings, and strengthening collaborations between experimental and theoretical research groups.
